content.raw: This will create `bbox` that won't cover all `coordinates` if they're all positive or all negative. I think it should be something like: `coordinates[:,i].min() - 0.1 * abs(coordinates[:,i].min()), coordinates[:,i].max() + 0.1 * abs(coordinates[:,i].max())`
content.html: This will create bbox that won't cover all coordinates if they're all positive or all negative. I think it should be something like: coordinates[:,i].min() - 0.1 * abs(coordinates[:,i].min()), coordinates[:,i].max() + 0.1 * abs(coordinates[:,i].max())

content.raw: What I am envisioning for caching here would be to iterate over all of the pixels (as we do now), then once we identify the node it intersects with, iterate over the bbox of that node.  Then that node would be marked as "done".  This should simplify the process of keeping some state for an element around, particularly if it's expensive to compute.
content.html: What I am envisioning for caching here would be to iterate over all of the pixels (as we do now), then once we identify the node it intersects with, iterate over the bbox of that node. Then that node would be marked as "done". This should simplify the process of keeping some state for an element around, particularly if it's expensive to compute.

content.raw: I think it's the first time, yes. Any file that tries to include an embree header needs to be compiled as C++ (so anything that cimports something for pyembree), because the embree headers contain things that aren't valid C code.
content.html: I think it's the first time, yes. Any file that tries to include an embree header needs to be compiled as C++ (so anything that cimports something for pyembree), because the embree headers contain things that aren't valid C code.

content.raw:
The other "Source" classes in the new VR (e.g. `VolumeSource`, `PointSource`, `LineSource`) all have `render()` that are called by the scene or camera object as opposed to directly as in the code above.  For example, something like the following would be more consistent with how the other "Source" classes work:


```
#!python

import yt
ds = yt.load(filename)
sc = Scene()
cam = Camera(ds)
sc.camera = cam
vr = VolumeSource(ds, field='density')
sc.add_source(vr)
ds2 = yt.load_unstructured_mesh(data, _connectivity, _coordinates)
ms = MeshSource(ds2, ('gas', 'diffused'))
sc.add_source(ms)
im = sc.render()
im.write_png("vr+ms.png")
```


It seems like this way of calling the `MeshSource` is preferred since it is consistent with the other "Source" classes, but perhaps there is a reason to break with that paradigm here that escapes me?
content.html:
The other "Source" classes in the new VR (e.g. VolumeSource, PointSource, LineSource) all have render() that are called by the scene or camera object as opposed to directly as in the code above. For example, something like the following would be more consistent with how the other "Source" classes work:

import yt
ds = yt.load(filename)
sc = Scene()
cam = Camera(ds)
sc.camera = cam
vr = VolumeSource(ds, field='density')
sc.add_source(vr)
ds2 = yt.load_unstructured_mesh(data, _connectivity, _coordinates)
ms = MeshSource(ds2, ('gas', 'diffused'))
sc.add_source(ms)
im = sc.render()
im.write_png("vr+ms.png")

It seems like this way of calling the MeshSource is preferred since it is consistent with the other "Source" classes, but perhaps there is a reason to break with that paradigm here that escapes me?

content.raw: Do you think it makes sense to have `yt.load()` check to see if something fits the criteria for being and unstructured mesh and then loads it if possible?
content.html: Do you think it makes sense to have yt.load() check to see if something fits the criteria for being and unstructured mesh and then loads it if possible?

content.raw: Nah, this fits the paradigm elsewhere -- `load_particles`, `load_octree`, `load_uniform_grid`, `load_amr_grids`.
content.html: Nah, this fits the paradigm elsewhere -- load_particles, load_octree, load_uniform_grid, load_amr_grids.

content.raw: Other than my comments below, LGTM.  Great work, @atmyers !
content.html: Other than my comments below, LGTM. Great work, Andrew Myers !

content.raw:
I agree with Matt - after we get the frontend PR ready, 
```
#!python

yt.load()
```
 will be used for on-disk datasets, and 
```
#!python

yt.load_unstructured_grid
```
 will still be for streaming datasets.
content.html:
I agree with Matt - after we get the frontend PR ready, 

yt.load()

will be used for on-disk datasets, and 

yt.load_unstructured_grid

will still be for streaming datasets.

content.raw: There's no reason, and ultimately, I want to be able to mix and match MeshSources with other RenderSource objects like you do here, particularly so I can do things like annotate mesh lines. Before that can happen, though, I need to implement zbuffering in MeshSource's render method. Right now, if you did the above, the image would just get overwritten by the call to MeshSource.render(). Would it be okay if I implemented that in a later PR?
content.html: There's no reason, and ultimately, I want to be able to mix and match MeshSources with other RenderSource objects like you do here, particularly so I can do things like annotate mesh lines. Before that can happen, though, I need to implement zbuffering in MeshSource's render method. Right now, if you did the above, the image would just get overwritten by the call to MeshSource.render(). Would it be okay if I implemented that in a later PR?

description:
This PR adds the ability to volume render unstructured mesh data. It includes:

1. The ability to sampler linear tetrahedral and hexahedral mesh elements at arbitrary interior points - this will also be useful for slices, among other things.
2. Unit tests of the above functions.
3. A new type of RenderSource for unstructured meshes.
4. Code to support casting rays at polygonal meshes using pyembree.
5. Updated pixelizer code that works with both hexahedral and tetrahedral mesh elements.

A sample notebook that demonstrates some of the new RenderSource is [here](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/e874240f3c7d5d2c8c28).

Sample scripts that demonstrate how to use the slicing capabilities are [here](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5782/) and [here](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5783/).

EDIT: I'm removing the WIP tag, I think this is ready for review.
